headline: Modest Thoughts From a Minor Donor to Harvard (opinion)
context: Responding to Harvard University’s defiance of the coercive and illegal demands from the Trump administration, some major donors have recently urged the university to make accommodations rather than fight. A few have withheld large gifts over the last year and a half.

Holding degrees from two of Harvard’s least wealthy schools (Divinity and Education), I have made small annual donations to my relatively impecunious alma maters for 45 years, and I offer these considerations to weigh against those of the big donors who have generally graduated from Harvard’s wealthiest, so-called major schools.

annotations.paragraph: Harvard’s resistance to authoritarian overreach bolsters the entire system of U.S. higher education, which came to be regarded as the best in the world only in the 1970s, after a century of slow development. Harvard’s defiance of unlawful authoritarianism inspires universities throughout the world.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on Harvard's role in resisting authoritarianism and its impact on global higher education.

annotations.paragraph: This controversy is therefore not just about Harvard, but all of higher education everywhere. If Harvard caves, then no university will dare to defy governmental overreach. If Harvard resists, then others will be inspired to do so and shamed if they do not.
annotations.reason: The paragraph expands on the broader implications of Harvard's actions for global higher education.

annotations.paragraph: The urging by major donors to strike a deal with the Trump administration may result from feeling that Harvard’s small and secretive governing board, the Corporation, has, in recent months, not listened to them and ignored “the rightward shift of the country” that prompted Trump’s demands. (Although Harvard’s “major" and wealthiest professional schools—business, law and medicine—still graduate leading financiers on Wall Street and conservative justices of the Supreme Court, notwithstanding claims about the university’s “sins” of left-wing radicalism.)
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the motivations of major donors and their relationship with Harvard's governance.

annotations.paragraph: In any case, the implied threat of major donors to withhold donations is transactional, just like the demands of the Trump administration. Thus, Harvard is caught between two transactional parties. Is the defiance of coercive and illegal overreach worth the possible loss in large gifts?
annotations.reason: The paragraph highlights the transactional nature of the situation and the dilemma faced by Harvard.

annotations.paragraph: And the loss could be considerable. Over the last century, the rule in higher education fundraising is that 90 percent of gifts come from the top 10 percent of donors. Big donors count. Little ones scarcely, it seems.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on the importance of major donors in higher education fundraising.
This sentence is vague and does not provide specific information.

annotations.paragraph: By adjusting the spending rule for its endowment income and by floating bonds and loans, Harvard does have the resources to supplant lost federal income until its legal challenges are litigated, notwithstanding the prospect of further demands by the Trump administration.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about Harvard's financial strategies to counteract lost federal income.

annotations.paragraph: Indeed, the annual investment income of large endowments vastly exceeds annual fundraising. As a result, wealthy universities were already shifting their focus from “gifts to growth” of investment yield by the beginning of the 21st century. Fundraising became less important than investing endowment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context on the financial strategies of wealthy universities, relevant to the discussion of Harvard's financial situation.

annotations.paragraph: Furthermore, major alumni donors, who might fear alienating the Trump administration by donating to Harvard, could easily make donations anonymously, which has long been a tradition in higher education.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about how donors can continue to support Harvard without public scrutiny.

annotations.paragraph: Finally, and most importantly, Harvard’s defiance has already inspired support from many alumni who may now do more, counterbalancing the support of transactional big donors who withdraw.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the impact of Harvard's stance on alumni support, directly related to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: I know that some little donors, like me, have not included Harvard in their estate plans precisely because Harvard has seemed so rich and invulnerable. As former president Drew Gilpin Faust once observed, Harvard’s commitment to its endowment could make the university “as close to immortal as any earthly institution might be.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the perception of Harvard's wealth and its impact on smaller donors.

annotations.paragraph: Now we see that Harvard needs the support of all of its alumni in these perilous times, not only for the sake of alma mater, but all of higher education.
annotations.reason: This paragraph emphasizes the need for alumni support, which is relevant to the discussion of donor contributions.
